name: Auto-Sync Local Events to Google Calendar with n8n

description:
# 

## Description

This workflow automates the process of finding local events and adding them directly to your Google Calendar. It eliminates the need for manual event tracking by automatically scraping event information and creating calendar entries.

## Overview

This workflow automates the process of finding local events and adding them to your Google Calendar. It uses Bright Data to scrape event information from a specified source and then creates new events in your calendar, ensuring you never miss out on what's happening around you.

### Tools Used

*   **n8n:** The automation platform that orchestrates the workflow.
*   **Bright Data:** For scraping event data from websites without getting blocked.
*   **Google Calendar API:** To create and manage calendar events.

## How to Install

1.  **Import the Workflow:** Download the `.json` file and import it into your n8n instance.
2.  **Configure Bright Data:** Add your Bright Data credentials to the Bright Data node.
3.  **Set Up Google Calendar:** Authenticate your Google Calendar account in the Google Calendar node.
4.  **Customize:** Adjust the workflow to target the specific websites and event types you're interested in.

## Use Cases

*   **Community Managers:** Keep track of local meetups and community events.
*   **Event Enthusiasts:** Never miss a concert, festival, or local gathering.
*   **Marketing Professionals:** Monitor competitor events and industry conferences.

---

## Connect with Me

*   **Website:** [https://www.nofluff.online](https://www.nofluff.online)
*   **YouTube:** [https://www.youtube.com/@YaronBeen/videos](https://www.youtube.com/@YaronBeen/videos)
*   **LinkedIn:** [https://www.linkedin.com/in/yaronbeen/](https://www.linkedin.com/in/yaronbeen/)
*   **Get Bright Data:** [https://get.brightdata.com/1tndi4600b25](https://get.brightdata.com/1tndi4600b25) (Using this link supports my free workflows with a small commission)

data.details: The Code node allows you to execute JavaScript in your workflow.

parameters.content:
## üß≠ **Section 1: Event Data Fetcher**

### üîÅ `üïí Daily Event Sync Trigger`

> **Node:** *Schedule Trigger*
> ‚è∞ This node sets **when** your automation runs. For example, you might want it to run every morning at 8:00 AM to check for new community events.

üîç Why it matters:

> This ensures your public calendar is always up to date without manual work.

---

### üåê `üåê Fetch Event Page (Bright Data)`

> **Node:** *HTTP Request using Bright Data Web Unlocker*
> üõ° This node sends a request to a **local government or library event page** using Bright Data‚Äôs **Web Unlocker proxy**, which helps bypass blocks or bot detection.

üîß What‚Äôs special here:

* It uses your **Bright Data proxy zone**
* It targets a public events URL (e.g., a `.gov` or `.org`)
* Makes sure you get the raw HTML page ‚Äî even if the site tries to hide it

‚úÖ Benefit:

> This lets you scrape data reliably from websites that are normally hard to reach for bots.

---

## üß© **Section 2: Smart Event Extractor**

### üß© `üß© Extract Event Data (HTML Parser)`

> **Node:** *HTML*
> üìÑ This node parses the raw HTML response from the website and extracts useful information like:

* üè∑ Event Titles
* üìç Locations
* üë• Target Audience
* ‚è∞ Raw Times

It uses selectors (like CSS) to grab content from specific parts of the page.

üéØ Goal:

> Transform messy website code into **structured data** you can actually use.

---

### üß† `üß† Clean & Format Event Data`

> **Node:** *Code*
> üßº This is the brain of your workflow. It takes the raw extracted data and:

* Matches titles with their correct time/location
* Skips garbage data like `"Date/Time"` headers
* üßÆ Converts time to proper ISO format (like `2025-06-21T11:00:00-07:00`) for Google Calendar

üöÄ Bonus:

> This ensures only **valid**, well-structured events are passed forward ‚Äî nothing broken, empty, or misaligned.

---

## üìÖ **Section 3: Auto Calendar Creator**

### üìÖ `üìÖ Create Google Calendar Events`

> **Node:** *Google Calendar*
> üßô‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è This node automatically **creates public calendar events** using the cleaned-up data.

Here‚Äôs what it sets:

* **Summary:** Event title
* **Description:** Full details (e.g., location, what it‚Äôs about)
* **Start/End Time:** In the correct Google Calendar format

            WORKFLOW ASSISTANCE

    Yaron@nofluff.online

Explore more tips and tutorials here:
   - YouTube: https://www.youtube.com/@YaronBeen/videos
   - LinkedIn: https://www.linkedin.com/in/yaronbeen/

# **üìÖ AutoSync Local Events to Google Calendar**

### *A No-Code Automation to Scrape, Clean, and Publish Community Events*

---
## üß≠ **Section 1: Event Data Fetcher**

### üîÅ `üïí Daily Event Sync Trigger`

> **Node:** *Schedule Trigger*
> ‚è∞ This node sets **when** your automation runs. For example, you might want it to run every morning at 8:00 AM to check for new community events.

üîç Why it matters:

> This ensures your public calendar is always up to date without manual work.

---

### üåê `üåê Fetch Event Page (Bright Data)`

> **Node:** *HTTP Request using Bright Data Web Unlocker*
> üõ° This node sends a request to a **local government or library event page** using Bright Data‚Äôs **Web Unlocker proxy**, which helps bypass blocks or bot detection.

üîß What‚Äôs special here:

* It uses your **Bright Data proxy zone**
* It targets a public events URL (e.g., a `.gov` or `.org`)
* Makes sure you get the raw HTML page ‚Äî even if the site tries to hide it

‚úÖ Benefit:

> This lets you scrape data reliably from websites that are normally hard to reach for bots.

---

## üß© **Section 2: Smart Event Extractor**

### üß© `üß© Extract Event Data (HTML Parser)`

> **Node:** *HTML*
> üìÑ This node parses the raw HTML response from the website and extracts useful information like:

* üè∑ Event Titles
* üìç Locations
* üë• Target Audience
* ‚è∞ Raw Times

It uses selectors (like CSS) to grab content from specific parts of the page.

üéØ Goal:

> Transform messy website code into **structured data** you can actually use.

---

### üß† `üß† Clean & Format Event Data`

> **Node:** *Code*
> üßº This is the brain of your workflow. It takes the raw extracted data and:

* Matches titles with their correct time/location
* Skips garbage data like `"Date/Time"` headers
* üßÆ Converts time to proper ISO format (like `2025-06-21T11:00:00-07:00`) for Google Calendar

üöÄ Bonus:

> This ensures only **valid**, well-structured events are passed forward ‚Äî nothing broken, empty, or misaligned.

---

## üìÖ **Section 3: Auto Calendar Creator**

### üìÖ `üìÖ Create Google Calendar Events`

> **Node:** *Google Calendar*
> üßô‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è This node automatically **creates public calendar events** using the cleaned-up data.

Here‚Äôs what it sets:

* **Summary:** Event title
* **Description:** Full details (e.g., location, what it‚Äôs about)
* **Start/End Time:** In the correct Google Calendar format

ü´∂ Why this matters:

> Now your scraped community events are published straight to a **Google Calendar** ‚Äî which you can embed on a website, share with citizens, or subscribe to.

---

## üß© Summary: Why This Workflow Rocks

| üîß Step              | üìå What It Does                                       | üéÅ Benefit to You                            |
| -------------------- | ----------------------------------------------------- | -------------------------------------------- |
| **Schedule Trigger** | Starts the automation daily                           | Keeps your calendar always fresh             |
| **HTTP Request**     | Grabs raw event info from a gov/library site          | Reliable access to public event data         |
| **HTML Parser**      | Pulls structured info from messy HTML                 | Turns code into useful content               |
| **Code Node**        | Fixes formatting, converts time, aligns titles & more | Clean data ready for use                     |
| **Calendar Node**    | Publishes events into your Google Calendar            | Fully automated public calendar ‚Äî no effort! |

---
